content:
• Thursday, November 3, 2016
  • LVS

    Improved Macau results lift Las Vegas Sands

    • Las Vegas Sands (NYSE:LVS) reports adjusted property EBITDA in Macau rose 15.3% to $628.5M in Q3. On a hold-normalized basis the growth was only 5.2%.
    • The new Parisian Macao casino contributed just over $19M of adjusted property EBITDA since opening on September 13.
    • Adjusted property EBITDA increased 6.9% to $85.3M in Las Vegas.
    • Shares of Las Vegas Sands rose 3.12% AH to $58.51.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:45 PM
  • WIFI

    Boingo sees loss widen, misses on revenues

    • Boingo Wireless (WIFI -2.6%) beat profit expectations with its Q3 results, though a 10% increase in revenues fell short of consensus and its loss widened from the prior year.
    • Cash flow went positive, at $10.1M, and growth was driven by strength in the company's distributed antenna system, military and wholesale Wi-Fi segments.
    • Net loss was $5.7M, vs. a year-ago loss of $4.8M. Adjusted EBITDA of $11.6M was up 36.5% and beat an expected $11M.
    • Connects grew to 40.26M from the prior year's 27.79M; Distributed antenna system nodes grew to 17.7K (in a record quarter) from 10.3K.
    • Revenue by segment: DAS, $15.96M (up 21.4%); Military, $10.1M (up 93%); Retail, $6.6M (down 14.6%); Wholesale-Wi-Fi, $5.9M (up 8%); Advertising and other, $2.2M (down 60.7%).
     
     
     
     
    | 7:38 PM
  • IPAS

    IPass -1.7% as revenues miss, loss narrows

    • IPass (IPAS -1.1%) has fallen 1.7% in postmarket action after it posted a loss and missed with revenues in its Q3 report.
    • The company lost $1.3M in GAAP terms and $0.4M in non-GAAP terms. Total revenue grew 6.1%.
    • Average monthly Wi-Fi network users grew 32% Y/Y (and 6% from Q2) to 133,000. Network usage in total hours consumed increased 57% Y/Y and 11% sequentially.
    • The company reaffirmed full-year revenue guidance (but at the bottom of its range of $63M-$68M, vs. consensus for $64.4M) and lowered guidance for full-year EBITDA to a loss of $4M to $3M.
    • "While our execution has improved dramatically, we have struggled in one area; turning deals into revenue as quickly as we had hoped," says CEO Gary Griffiths. But with a backlog of revenue tied to a bookings-to-billings gap, "we expect we will be able to guide to double-digit revenue growth next year," he says.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:30 PM
  • EVC

    Entravision misses in Q3 with 'challenging' comps

    • Entravision Communication (EVC -1.6%) missed with its Q3 earnings as revenue slipped 6%, wiping out nine-month gains from 2015.
    • The company faced "challenging comparisons" to the prior year, said CEO Walter Ulloa. Core TV ad revenue continued to grow, but sales were hurt by the loss of telecom non-advertising revenues.
    • Revenue by segment: Television, $40.3M (down 7%); Radio, $19.2M (down 8%); Digital, $5.75M (up 15%).
    • The decrease in TV was partly offset by an increase in national ad revenues as well as an increase in political advertising and retransmission consent revenues.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:18 PM
  • MDCA

    MDC Partners -21.4% as it misses in Q3, suspends dividend

    • MDC Partners (MDCA +0.6%) has tumbled off a cliff, down 21.4% in postmarket action after its Q3 earnings featured a revenue miss and lowered guidance as it embarks on restructuring.
    • An adjusted net loss of $0.64/share was pushed heavily by a noncash goodwill charge of $29.6M related to the company's experiential business. Adjusted EBITDA fell 13.5%, to $46.3M (well below an expected $58M); EBITDA margin was 13.2%. Revenue grew 6.3% on a headline basis but just 2.7% organically.
    • The company suspended its dividend, applying those resources to "accelerated de-leveraging and strategic growth initiatives."
    • A cloud showed up over the company last week as speculators connected it with a report that the SEC was investing the use of non-GAAP metrics (though MDC wasn't named).
    • MDC lowered revenue guidance for the full year to $1.365B-$1.375B from the previous $1.39B-$1.42B (and below consensus for $1.395B), and cut guidance for EBITDA to $170M-$180M from a previous $205M-$215M (below consensus for $206.3M).
     
     
     
     
    | 6:26 PM
  • TEUM

    Pareteum gains 14% as it embarks on new name with Brazil deal

    • In its first day under a new name and symbol, Pareteum (NYSEMKT:TEUM) rose 14% today after it announced a strategic partnership with Cleartech Brazil.
    • The former Elephant Talk Communications (ETAK) hooked up with the Brazilian systems integrator to help deploy its Mobile Virtual Network Enabler services to enterprise and MVN operators.
    • Brazil's considered one of the largest MVNO markets in the world, Pareteum says, after the approval of related regulations in 2010. The market has the potential to grow to more than 50M mobile clients over the next decade.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:06 PM
  • GSAT

    Globalstar rebounds in postmarket after Q3 earnings beat

    • Globalstar (GSAT -8.9%), which tumbled into the close on a high-volume day, has made back nearly all of the day's losses in postmarket (up 8.8%) following its Q3 earnings beat.
    • Revenues grew 8% and service revenue increased 12%, while net income swung to a loss of $2.6M (break-even per share) from a year-ago gain of $24.1M. That beat expectations for a loss of $0.02/share, though.
    • Service gains came from a growing subscriber base along with increased average revenue per user, Globalstar said. The gains were tied to growth in SPOT and Duplex service revenues.
    • Revenue breakout: Service revenues, $21.95M (up 11.7%); Subscriber equipment sales, $3.59M (down 11%).
    • Subscribers grew to 77,485 from 75,303 in Duplex; to 276,384 from 258,812 in SPOT; and to 39,318 from 38,725 in IGO, while they declined in Simplex slightly, to 298,186 from 302,460.
    • ARPU rose to $40.02 from $32.80 in Duplex; to $11.65 from $11.33 in SPOT; and to $2.02 from $1.63 in IGO, while it fell to $2.56 from $260 in Simplex.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:56 PM | 3 Comments
  • LXU

    LSB Industries to explore strategic alternatives, including potential sale

    • LSB industries (NYSE:LXU) +4.6% AH after reporting alongside its Q3 earnings that it is exploring potential strategic alternatives, which may include a sale of the company, a merger or another strategic transaction involving some or all of its assets.
    • LSB says it has hired Morgan Stanley as its financial advisor to assist with the strategic review process.
    • LSB says the soft selling price environment for its agricultural products persisted during Q3, and it expects only modest change, other than perhaps short-term seasonal uplifts, for the next several quarters.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:54 PM | 2 Comments
  • INVN

    InvenSense 5% lower after hours, consumer and mobile market weakness cited in Q2 report

    • Results – revenue $79.83M (-29.1% Y/Y, $0.16 above estimates), EPS $0.02 ($0.01 below estimates), gross margin 46% (unchanged Q/Q), net income $1.7M (vs. $4.9M net loss Q/Q)
    • InvenSense (NYSE:INVN) president and CEO: "The InvenSense team delivered solid results in the second fiscal quarter. We are encouraged that our R&D investments are beginning to pay off with new design wins which we anticipate will allow us to penetrate new markets. While the consumer and mobile markets were and remain soft, we believe this design win activity will position us for strong top line growth in fiscal 2018 as we strive to diversify our business."
    • Prior quarters overview

    | 5:44 PM | 2 Comments

  • HLF

    Herbalife +1.5% as Icahn bumps stake to 23.05%

    • Herbalife (NYSE:HLF) shares have a postmarket bump going, up 1.5%, as an SEC filing shows Carl Icahn has bumped his stake again, to 23.05% from a previous 20.78%.
    • The stock made a move up into the close to finish up 1.1% during market hours after spending the day in the red.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:28 PM | 158 Comments
  • STRZA

    Lions Gate revenues mark strong gains on bigger film slate

    • Lions Gate Entertainment (LGF -3.9%) beat expectations with fiscal Q2 results that the company figures are its last before a merger with Starz (NASDAQ:STRZA).
    • The company posted a net loss of $17.5M (narrower than the year prior), adjusted to a net income of $16.9M. Revenue grew 34% with strong results in both core segments.
    • Adjusted EBITDA swung from a loss to a positive $2.6M, missing an expected $5.6M.
    • Revenue by segment: Motion Pictures, $464.4M (up 31.2%); Television Production, $175.1M (up 43%).
    • In motion pictures, a bigger release slate meant theatrical revenue more than doubled, to $62M, while TV revenues from that segment were up 16% to $69.3M.
    • Home entertainment revenue from motion picture and TV production increased 5% to $160.7M. Filmed entertainment backlog (revenue contracted but not yet recorded) hung at $1.5B.
    • Segment profit: Motion Pictures, $6.6M (vs. a year-ago loss of $390K); Television Production, $12.1M (up 140%).
     
     
     
     
    | 5:20 PM | 1 Comment
  • LJPC

    • Revenue of $0.04M (-93.8% Y/Y) misses by $0.13M.

    | 5:17 PM
  • TWLO

    Twilio -4.6% despite surpassed Q3 expectations

    • Results – Total revenue $71.53M (+61.6% Y/Y, $4.76M above estimates), EPS -$0.04 ($0.04 above estimates), Base revenue $64.1M (+75% Y/Y), loss from operations $3.4M (vs. $4.6M loss Y/Y)
    • Operational metrics – 34.457K active customer accounts as of September 30 (vs. 23.822K Y/Y), dollar-based net expansion rate 155% (vs. 156% Y/Y)
    • Q4 projections – Total revenue $72.5M-$74.5M, Base revenue $68M-$69M, loss from operations $5.5M-$4.5M, loss per share $0.06-$0.05
    • FY 2016 projections – Total revenue $268M-$270M, Base revenue $238.5-$239.5M, loss from operations $18M-$17M, loss per share $0.23-$0.21
    • Share price summary – 1-month, -49%; 3-month, -23%
    • Yesterday: Secondary offering further ammunition for wagers against Twilio
    • Conference call
    • 8-K

  • GLUU

    Glu Mobile +5.7%; takes control of Crowdstar, elevates new CEO

    • Glu Mobile (GLUU +3.2%) is tacking on gains in the postmarket session, now up 5.7% more, after its Q3 results featured declining revenues and bookings Y/Y.
    • In strategic news, Glu took a controlling interest in Crowdstar, "a leader in fashion and styling games for women." And it named Nick Earl its CEO, and current CEO Niccolo de Masi is transitioning to executive chairman.
    • Glu saw some royalty impairments from underperforming titles, de Masi said, but “Our third quarter bookings were driven by the continued traction of Tap Sports Baseball 2016, Cooking Dash 2016 and Racing Rivals, as well as the launch of Gordon Ramsay Dash and ongoing success of Kim Kardashian: Hollywood.”
    • For Q4, Glu expects bookings of $46M-$48M, and adjusted gross margin of about 64.6%. For the full year, it's forecasting bookings at $202.2M-$204.2M, with adjusted gross margin of about 48%. It expects to have cash and short-term investments at year-end of at least $80M.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:51 PM | 8 Comments

    GoPro resumes trade down 22%

  • GPRO

    GoPro off Q3 calculations, shares halted after hours

    • Results – revenue $240.57M (-39.9% Y/Y, $72.16M below estimates), EPS -$0.60 ($0.26 below estimates)
    • Q4 projections – revenue $625M (+/- $25M), gross margin 40% (+/- 1%), EPS $0.30 (+/- $0.05), tax rate 12%
    • FY 2016 projections – revenue $1.25B-$1.3B
    • FY 2017 projections – "Double digit year-over-year revenue growth," operating expenses $650M, "net income profitable," tax rate 15%
    • GoPro (NASDAQ:GPRO) founder and CEO Nicholas Woodman: "These are the best products we've ever made and consumer demand is strong. GoPro (GPRO) is now a seamless storytelling experience and we're very happy with customer reception so far. Looking forward to 2017, we expect to return to profitability, driven by the strength of our new products, double digit revenue growth and annual operating expenses of approximately $650 million."

  • ATVI

    Activision Blizzard -5.5% after setting holiday quarter guidance

    • Activision Blizzard (ATVI +1.8%) has slipped 5.5% after hours following its Q3 profit beat, which featured a guidance raise still below consensus for the holiday quarter.
    • Revenues hit a Q3 record $1.57B (in accordance with GAAP); those revenues from digital channels were an all-time record of $1.34B.
    • Revenue breakout: Product sales, $355M (down 16.5%); Subscription, licensing and other, $1.21B (up 115).
    • The company's raising guidance for full-year net revenues (now to $6.45B non-GAAP, vs. $6.56B consensus) and EPS (to $1.92 vs. expected $1.98), and expects Q4 revenues of $1.86B (vs. $2.45B consensus) and EPS of $0.40 (vs. consensus for $0.79).
    • Conference call to come at 4:30 p.m. ET.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:31 PM | 20 Comments

  • FEYE

    FireEye +15%, Q3 over predictions

    • Results – revenue $186.4M (+13% Y/Y, $3.75M above estimates), EPS -$0.18 ($0.13 above estimates), billings $215.4M (+2% Y/Y), gross margin 74% (vs. 73% Y/Y), operating margin -14% (vs. -32% Y/Y), cash flow from operations $14.1M (vs. -$8.3M Y/Y)
    • Q4 projections – revenue $187M-$193M, billings $230M-$250M, gross margin 74%, operating margin -11% to -13%, EPS -$0.16 to -$0.18, cash flow from operations -$19M to -$29M
    • FY 2016 projections – revenue $716M-$722M, billings $828M-$848M, gross margin 73%, operating margin -22% to -23%, EPS -$1.14 to -$1.16, cash flow from operations -$41M to -$51M
    • FireEye (NASDAQ:FEYE) CEO Kevin Mandia: "Today we announced the introduction of Cloud MVX and MVX Smart Grid, expanding the form factors and deployment architectures of our security platform to deliver security from the cloud. I believe we are in the early phases of the richest new innovation cycle in our history, and these are the first of many planned releases that will help customers elevate their security profile at a lower total cost of ownership. The investments we've made in intelligence, orchestration, and integration are redefining the FireEye security platform and creating new engines for growth."

  • SBUX

    Margins and comparable sales track higher at Starbucks

    • Starbucks (NASDAQ:SBUX) is higher after edging past estimates with its FQ4 report.
    • The company reported global comparable store sales rose 4% during the quarter vs. +4.9% expected by analysts.
    • The average ticket was up 5% at comparable stores, while the total number of transactions was down 1% from a year ago.
    • Comp growth by region: Americas and U.S. +5%; EMEA -1%; China/Asia Pacific +1% (+6% in China vs. +5.4% expected).
    • U.S. comparable store sales were up 4% on a 6% boost in average ticket. Mobile Order and Pay accounted for 6% of sales, up a point sequentially.
    • The company's operating margin increased 180 bps to 21.5%.
    • FY17 guidance: Starbucks expects mid single-digit global comparable sales growth. Double-digit revenue growth is also anticipated. The company forecasts a net addition of 2.1K stores during the year. Non-GAAP EPS of $2.12 to $2.14 is expected.
    • Previously: Starbucks beats by $0.01, beats on revenue (Nov. 3)
    • SBUX -3.48% AH to $51.77.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:20 PM | 15 Comments
  • CBS

    CBS +2.3% after Q3 marks solid beat on top, bottom lines

    • CBS (CBS +0.6%) is up another 2.3% after hours following a beat on top and bottom lines, in a season marked as much by speculation about a Viacom re-merger than its continuing strong results.
    • The company showed growth in profits and revenues across all segments. Revenues were up 4% overall, to $3.4B, as retransmission fees from affiliates grew 32%. Content licensing and distribution revenues were up 6%.
    • Adjusted EPS grew 19% to $1.05, easily beating an expected $0.98.
    • Revenues by segment: Entertainment, $1.95B (up 0.9%); Cable Networks, $598M (up 13.7%); Publishing, $226M (up 11.3%); Local Media, $409M (up 8.8%); Radio, $319M (up 0.3%). In preparing for the spin-off of CBS Radio, segments have been reclassified; Local Broadcasting has become two segments, Local Media and Radio.
    • Revenues by type: Advertising, $1.47B (down 0.8%); Content licensing and distribution, $1.11B (up 5.9%); Affiliate and subscription fees, $753M (up 13.4%).
    • Conference call to come at 4:30 p.m. ET.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:17 PM | 1 Comment

  • TROX

    Tronox surges 10% after Q3 beat, strong TiO2 pricing picture

    • Tronox (TROX +9.6%) spikes as much as 20% before settling for a ~10% gain near the close, ranking as today's top performer on the Russell 2000 Materials & Processing index after reporting a smaller than expected Q3 loss.
    • Q3 TiO2 segment revenue of $339M came in 11% lower than the year-ago $380M, primarily the result of lower sales volumes for CP titanium slag and pig iron; Q3 alkali segment revenue of $194M was nearly even with last year's $195M, as 3% higher sales volumes were offset by 3% lower selling prices.
    • Alembic Global, which rates the stock at Overweight with an $11 price target, says better than expected Q3 EBITDA was based on favorable TiO2 pricing and volume strength, noting that the trough in the TiO2 cycle may have been left behind.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:57 PM
  • PTCT

    European regulatory uncertainty regarding Translarna sinks PTC Therapeutics; shares down 34%

    • Micro cap PTC Therapeutics (PTCT -34.2%) slumps on more than triple normal volume in response to a statement it made after the close yesterday concerning the ongoing availability of Duchenne muscular dystrophy med Translarna (ataluren) in Europe.
    • Translarna has been commercially available in the EU since 2014 subject to annual renewal and certain other conditions. The company says that following its October meeting with the advisory committee CHMP, it requested additional information regarding the risk-benefit profile of Translarna, its efficacy and the design of a pivotal trial that would provided comprehensive data. The company has responded to CHMP's requests, but adds that "recent dialogue has introduced a higher degree of uncertainty as to the outcome" [of its renewal].
    • Translarna is a protein restoration therapy designed to enable the formation of a functioning protein in patients with nonsense mutation-caused genetic disorders. It accounts for all of the company's sales.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:54 PM | 4 Comments
  • AAC

    AAC Holdings Q3 shy of consensus; earnings guidance lowered; shares plunge 51%

    • Thinly traded micro cap AAC Holdings (AAC -50.5%) is getting roughed today on a 19x surge volume after Q3 results fell short of consensus.
    • Results ($M): Revenues: 68.5 (+0.04%);
    • Net Income: (2.5) (-136.6); Non-GAAP Net Income: 4.3 (-66.2%); Non-GAAP EBITDA: 12.1 (-67.0%); EPS: (0.11) (-120.0%); Non-GAAP EPS: 0.19 (-66.7%); CF Ops (9 mo.): 1.3 (-77.4%).
    • 2016 Guidance: Revenues: $275M - 280M from $275M - 285M; Non-GAAP EBITDA: $47M - 49M; Non-GAAP EPS: $0.69 - 0.77 from $0.85 - 0.90.
    • Census view was non-GAAP EPS of $0.23 on revenues of $73.3M.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:33 PM
  • XEC

    Cimarex Energy -5% after cutting production outlook

    • Cimarex Energy (XEC -5.3%) plunges to its biggest loss in eight months after cutting production guidance.
    • XEC's Q3 earnings came in ahead of analyst consensus and revenues were only slightly below expectations, but production of 947M cfe/day was slightly below company guidance, caused by several factors including higher than anticipated ethane rejection and the timing of new well completions and subsequent production as well as production shut in during completion operations.
    • XEC cuts estimated Q4 production to 945M-985M cfe/day to reflect project delays, resulting in reduced FY 2016 production guidance to 960M-970M cfe/day from its previous outlook of 980M-1B cfe/day.
    • XEC's new completion schedule moves 10 net well completions previously scheduled for Q4 into early 2017, bringing total net wells completed in 2016 to 62 from the previous expectation of 72 net wells; 2016 capex is now estimated at $785M, up from $750M previously.

  • TRIL

    Preliminary early-stage data on Trillium's lead product candidate show potential safety issue; shares crater 49%

    • Thinly traded nano cap Trillium Therapeutics (TRIL -49.1%) plummets on an 18x surge in volume in response to an ASH abstract detailing interim results from a Phase 1 study assessing the safety, tolerability and maximum tolerated dose of lead product candidate TTI-621 (SIRPalphaFc), a recombinant fusion protein that binds to CD47, a transmembrane protein that is overexpressed in many tumors and enables the cancer cells to avoid detection by the immune system.
    • Data from 11 blood cancer patients showed TTI-621 was reasonably well-tolerated in the 0.05 mg/kg (n=3), 0.1 mg/kg (n=3) and 0.3 mg/kg (n=5) cohorts. The majority experienced mild-to-moderate infusion-related events. Transient dose-dependent decreases in platelets and leukocytes occurred in the hours following infusion in all patients. Two of the five patients in the highest dose cohort experienced reversible, dose-limiting toxicity, including Grade 3 elevated liver enzymes and Grade 4 thrombocytopenia (low blood platelets). Dosing at 0.2 mg/kg is now being investigated. Hemoglobin levels remained stable or improved with treatment.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:14 PM | 3 Comments

  • ACHN

    Achillion slumps 33% on potential safety issue with PNH candidate ACH-4471

    • Achillion Pharmaceuticals (ACHN -33.1%) plummets on more than triple normal volume in apparent response to the company's report of Phase 1 data regarding ACH-4471, a factor D inhibitor in development for the treatment of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) and atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome (aHUS).
    • The early-stage study explored the safety, pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics of ACH-4471. As far as safety signals were concerned, there were two cases of self-limited grade 3 (5 - 10x the upper limit of normal or ULN) and grade 4 (greater than 10x ULN) elevations in a liver enzyme called alanine transaminase (ALT) which is a biomarker of liver damage. They were observed after treatment in the mid- and high-dose groups. There were no signs of symptoms of hepatic decompensation and both patients' ALT returned to normal without intervention during follow-up. Additionally, no treatment-related fever or infections were observed.
    • The company says preliminary results from the study should be available in the first half of next year.
    • The treatment of PNH and aHUS, both orphan diseases, is dominated by Alexion Pharmaceuticals' (ALXN +2.4%) Soliris (eculizumab). ACH-4471 is orally administered while Soliris is an intravenous formulation.
